On Tue, 25 May 2004 09:54:49 -0500, Philip Tucker <ptucker@...> wrote:
> 
> > In SharpNEAT I opted for (2) as in Ken's implemenatation. My logic being
> > that I thought matching like innovations is beneficial but costly in
> > terms of CPU time. So I figured this gives a good balance. However I
> > just traced a bug whereby evolved networks where seen - by Ken - to have
> > multiple recurrent connections on a single node. I realise now that this
> > is a result of crossover between two genomes that contained the same
> > connection, but with a different innovation ID. To fix this I should
> > check for duplicate connections within genomes created by crossover,
> > which erodes some of the performance gain obtained from using technique
> > (2).
> 
> That's a good point.  How did you handle that case in your
> implementation, Ken?  If 2 chromosomes crossover where each has a
> connection between nodes 1 and 2, btu where the connections have
> different innovation IDs, do you sum the genotype weights to create
> the phenotype connection weight?  Or average them?  Or discard one?

I would imagine you'd follow the general NEAT methodology of having
the topology from the dominant individual take precedence.  So if you
had a connection between the same two nodes in two individuals that
were crossing over, you'd discard the connection from the less fit
individual and use the connection and associated weight from the
fitter individual.

Derek
